div1.head: Report, by Juan Guiteras, [1907?]
div1.p:
Guiteras re Nobel prize for Finlay &
Agramonte

The Faculty of Medicine and Pharmacy of the University of Habana
approved unanimously the following argument presented by a committee of
the Faculty, composed of Drs. Guiteras, Menocal and Ortega, in support
of a motion to present the claims of Drs. C.J. Finlay and Aristides Agra-
monte for the Nobel prize in Medicine.

The benefits secured to humanity by the discovery of the transmis-
sion of yellow fever by the mosquito can be equalled only by those deriv-
ed from the discovery of vaccination by Jenner, the production of anti-
diphtheric serum by Behring, the demonstration of the nature of surgical
infections by Pasteur and Koch, and of the anopheline transmission of
malaria, by Grassi and Ross.

If all these discoveries be comparable with that relating to yellow
fever from the viewpoint of the number of lives saved; the discovery of
Jenner is the only one comparable with it, in that they both tend very
decidedly, if not surely, to bring about the complete extinction of two
grave epidemic diseases; the yellow fever has disappeared from the great
foci of its perennial incidence, Habana, Vera Crus, Panama, Rio.

The participation of our two candidates in this great work may be
expressed as follows:

The happy conception, never before imagined by another mind of
the transmission of yellow fever from the sick to the well through the
mosquito, belongs to Dr. Finlay. This idea, together with that of Dr.
Manson concerning the transmission of the filaria by the mosquito, are
the foundations upon which rest the new doctrine and the discoveries of
the transmission of diseases by blood-sucking insects.

Dr. Finlay was not satisfied with the simple enunciation of a theory.
He dedicated his energies to the demonstration and the promulgation of
the same, as may be seen in the long series of papers published by him
Date? Sometime after 1907 - See p 6
2.
since the first announcement of his views in 1881. Many of these papers
will appear in the volume of his works, which, edited by the Cuban Govern-
ment, is to accompany these claims.
The following publications may be here mentioned:

Actas de la Conferencia sanitaria de Washington, 1881, Anales de la
Academia de Ciencias de la Habana, t. XVII, p. 449.

El mosquito hipoteticamente considerado como agente de transmission
de la fiebre smarilla. Anales de la Acad. de Ciencias de la Hab. t. XVIII
p. 147, Agosto de 1881.

Patogenia de la fiebre amarilla, Anal. de la Acad. de Ciencias de la
Hab. t. XIX p. 160. Agosto de 1882.

Sur une nouvelle theorie de la fievre jauns. Arch. de Med. Navale t.
XXXIX pp. 67, 90 y 307.

Nuevos datos acarca de la relacion entre la fiebre amarilla y el mos-
quito. Anal. de la Acad. de Ciencias de la Hab. t. XIX, p. 445.

Fiebre amarilla experimental comparada con la natural en sus formas
bomignas. Cron. Med. quir. de la Hab. t. X, pp. 51 y 91, 1884.
Apuntes sobre la historia primitiva de la fiebre amarilla, 1884, y 1885.

Yellow fever, its transmission by the Culex mosquito, Amer. Jour. of the
Med. Sciences, Oct., 1886.

Estadiatica de las inoculaciones con mosquitos contaminados en enfer-
mos de fiebre amarilla, Anal. de la Acad. de Ciencias de la Hab. t. XXVII,
p. 501, 1890.

Inoculations of yellow fever by means of contaminated mosquitos, Amer.
Jour. of the Med. Sciences, Sept., 1891.

Yellow fever immunity; modes of propagation by mosquito theory. Comptes
rend- du 8 me. Cong. Intern. d'Hyg. et Demogr. Budapest, 1894.
Celbos Fieber, Handb. der prakt. Med. Ebstein u. Schwalbe, 1900.

Is the mosquito the only agent through which yellow fever is transmit-
ted! Trans. of the First Intern. Sun. Cong. Of the Amer. Republics, Washington,
Dec., 1902.

Method of stamping out yellow fever suggested since 1899. Conf. of
State and Prov. Boards of Health, Oct., 1902.

Dr. Finlay's demonstration consisted in a profound study of bionomy
of the insect, with a series of experiments showing the influence upon the
Stegomyia of meteorologic and telluric phenomena which were proven to be
incompatible with the propagation and activities of the insect. These
conditions, Dr. Finlay showed, were the same that were incompatible with the
propagation of yellow fever. He subjected the insects, their larvae and
their eggs, to alterations of the temperature, the atmospheric pressure,
the conditions of the environment with respect to the presence or absence
of water, and to the operation of accidents from transportation in artifi-
cial conditions. He demonstrated that all these agencies coincided with
3.
conditions that affected the propagation of the disease, and he determined
with precision the point where the adverse conditions ended and the favorable
ones began.

The only mosquito which adjusted itself to these and other conditions,
was the Stegomyia calopus, an insect which was also, as he pointed out, es-
sentially a domestic mosquito and a weak flyer. He also showed that the same
insect could be easily made to bite at regular intervals different persons,
whether sick or well, which was not the case with other mosquitos.

From these data Dr. Finlay logically derived the conclusions which he
tenaciously maintained during the 20 years preceding the labors of the Ameri-
can Commission; conclusions that may be formulated in the statement that the
transmission of yellow fever from the sick to the well through the instru-
mentality of the mosquito was the only viable explanation of the epidemiolo-
gic phenomena of that disease.

Dr. Finlay endeavored also to demonstrate the truth of his conclusions
by other means, namely, by the direct experimentation. This endeavor marks
him as the first to apply infected insects experimentally with a view to pro-
duce pathologic phenomena of the same kind, and gave the opportunity to in-
vent the technique of this method of inoculations.

Convinced of the truth of his discovery, he invented and proposed a
complete plan of a prophylactic campaign against yellow fever, the same plan
which, accepted later on, has produced the wonderful results that we are all
familiar with.

Though it might be maintained, from our viewpoint of today, that the
epidemiologic and bionomic demonstrations of Dr. Finlay should have been
sufficient, and that our non-acceptance of them was more due to our lack of
attention and of complete knowledge than to defects in the proofs themselves,
yet it is a fact that the said proofs did not carry conviction to the scien-
4.
tific world, and nothing practical came from the vigorous discussions sustain-
ed by our clearsighted compatriot. This was due, more than to anything else,
to the negative results obtained in his ingenious and original experiments of
inoculation by the mosquito.

The practical acceptance of the mosquito doctrine was due to the conclu-
sive demonstration produced by the Commission of medical officers of the United
States Army, Drs. Walter Reed, James Carroll, Aristides Agramonte and Jesse W.
Lazear.

In the year 1900 the said commission established its laboratories and
experimental camp in a secluded spot of the military reservation at Camp Co-
lumbia, near Habana; a place where the presence of a large body of non-immunes
without manifestations of the disease proved the absence of the yellow fever
infection. Here, the undisputed demonstration of the transmission of yellow
fever by the Stegomyio mosquito was obtained in a series of most brilliant
experiments.

The direct experimentation in the human being was employed, adapting
the recently acquired knowledge of the transmission of malaria to the pro-
cess of experimentation initiated by Finlay.

Non-immune men were subjected to all the agencies of contagion that
the most ingenious investigation could suggest, without producing a single
case; the application, on the other hand, of infected mosquitos under cer-
tain conditions produced the amarillic infection.

Within a building divided in two by a partition of wire gauze men
were placed, on the one side of the partition, exposed to all sorts of
fomites, bed clothing, etc., contaminated with all kinds of discharges
from yellow fever patients, but with the exclusion of mosquitos. On the
other side of the partition men were placed with infected mosquitos. Yel-
low fever was produced only in this second group. Numbers of cases were
produced among the men isolated in that camp by the application of mosquitos,
5.
without the disease propagating to anyone of the other men who were kept in
the same camp. It was proven that the yellow fever patient was infective
during the first days of the disease solely, and that the mosquito became
infective only after the expiration of 12 days since drawing the infected
blood. The period of the incubation of the disease was established. It
was proven that yellow fever, like malaria, could be transmitted by the
direct inoculation of blood hypodermically. It was proven that patients
infected in either one of these two ways, were capable of transferring the
disease to others, so that the virus was something living, capable of mul-
tiplication in the blood.

These experiments were subsequently repeated by Guiteras in the Las
Animas Hospital, and later on by national and foreign commissions in Bra-
zil and Mexico, thus fulfilling the provision of experimental comprobation
by other authors, as required by the Nobel foundation.

Based on the conclusive demonstration of the American Commission, the
sanitary authorities in Cuba established the prophylactic plan proposed by
Finlay. This plan has been copied by other infected regions. The result
has been most extraordinary; to wit: the progressive reduction of the zone
of distribution of yellow fever, the reduction to insignificant proportions
of the remaining foci, the saving of hundreds of thousands of lives, the
opening to immigration of the sparsely peopled tropical regions of America,
and the possibility to forecast that yellow fever may perish from the earth.

The acceptance of the mosquito doctrine as to yellow fever, and the
practical application of the doctrine, was the result of the work of the
American Commission. In the bases of its constitution this Commission es-
tablished that the results of their labors should be held as common to all
the members. The only living member of the said Commission is Dr. Agramonte,
an exiled Cuban who, because of distinguished merits, had been honored by a
6.
foreign Government with this important and delicate mission. He alone re-
presents today the part that the Commission took in the solution of the
problem, and to him alone corresponds the reward that attaches to that part
of the work.
The following publications of Dr. Agramonte may be here mentioned:

The etiology of yellow fever (preliminary note) in colaboration with
Drs. Reed, Carroll and Lazear, Phila. Med. Jour., Oct. 27, 1900.

The etiology of yellow fever (additional note) in colaboration with
Drs. Reed, and Carroll, - Third Pan-Amer. Med. Cong., Feb., 1901.

Experimental yellow fever, in colaboration with Drs. Reed and Carroll,
American Medicine, July, 1901.

Anotaciones acerca de la etiologia de la fiebre amarilla, - Rev. de
Med. y Cir. Habans, Aguste de 1901.

Mosquitos and yellow fever. Illustrated chapter with eight drawings
in “Laboratory work with mosquitos”, by W. N. Berkeley, New York, 1902.

Epidemiology of yellow fever. Read before the XIV Intern. Cong. of
Hygiene and Demogr. Berlin, Sept., 1907.

If we consider fairly the two names mentioned in the motion before the
Faculty, Dr. Finlay and Dr. Agramonte, who represent two distinct phases of
this glorious evolution, it appears to us that neither one of the two scien-
tists could have attained final success without the labors of the other; the
teachings of Finlay would have continued in the void that was created about
them, and the American Commission would have commenced their labors without
the solid foundation upon which the superstructure of success was builded.

So evidently do these two endeavors complete each other, so intimate is
the connection between the claims of these two exponents of the several as-
pects of the problem, that we are forced to confess that the cause of the
delay in presenting their titles for the proper reward is the very fact they
had not earlier joined their interests in this most just demand.

The glory is sufficiently great to crown both endeavors, and the reward
should be equally divided between the two survivors.
(Signed) Juan Guiteras.
